source.name: City of Ottawa / Circular Materials
source.notes: Based on official City of Ottawa blue bin guidelines. As of Jan 2026, managed by Circular Materials. Food-soiled aluminum foil accepted. Alcohol containers over 100ml go to The Beer Store.

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass accepted
Items must be placed loose in the bin — max 15kg weight
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in garbage
Don't include ceramics, drinking glasses, or window glass

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Remove metal lids (recycle metal lids separately)
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include ceramic containers

materials.name: Food and beverage cans
notes: All metal food and beverage cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Aluminum beverage cans
notes: Alcohol containers over 100ml should go to The Beer Store for deposit return
commonMistakes: Don't crush — keep 3-dimensional for sorting
Alcohol containers over 100ml → The Beer Store

materials.name: Metal jar lids
notes: Metal lids accepted separately
commonMistakes: Small lids may fall through sorting — place inside a can and crimp closed if possible

materials.name: Aluminum containers and foil
instructions: Clean or food-soiled aluminum foil and containers are both accepted
Ball foil into a fist-sized ball
notes: Ottawa accepts food-soiled aluminum foil — unusual and convenient
No need to scrub foil perfectly clean
commonMistakes: Don't include foil-lined chip bags — those are garbage

materials.name: Empty paint cans
instructions: Must be completely empty and dry
notes: Only empty, dry paint cans — wet paint cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with paint residue — those go to hazardous waste depot

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't include if still pressurized

materials.name: Spiral-wound canisters with metal ends
notes: Spiral-wound cardboard canisters with metal ends are accepted in Ottawa
commonMistakes: Must have metal ends to be accepted

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs
notes: Rigid plastic containers #1-7 accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic jars
notes: Rigid plastic jars #1-7 accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily contaminated with food

materials.name: Plastic takeout and bakery containers
notes: Rigid plastic takeout, bakery, and produce containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include foam containers — those are garbage
Rinse to remove food residue

materials.name: Plastic pails and planting trays
notes: Rigid plastic garden items accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily encrusted with soil — clean first

materials.name: Yogurt cups and tubs
notes: All rigid plastic dairy containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include foil lids — peel off and recycle foil separately

materials.name: Clear plastic egg cartons
notes: Clear plastic egg cartons accepted (not foam)
commonMistakes: Don't include foam egg cartons — those are garbage

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
notes: Gable-top cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten

materials.name: Drink boxes / juice boxes
notes: Drink boxes and juice boxes accepted
commonMistakes: Remove straw and straw wrapper — those go in garbage

materials.name: Soup and broth cartons
notes: Aseptic (Tetra Pak) cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten

materials.name: Flexible plastic packaging (NEW 2026)
instructions: NEW in 2026: flexible plastic packaging now accepted in the blue bin
notes: As of 2026, Circular Materials expanded Ottawa's blue bin to accept flexible plastic packaging
This is a major change — previously these went to garbage
commonMistakes: This is new for 2026 — previously went in garbage
Don't include heavily soiled film

materials.name: Foam packaging (NEW 2026)
instructions: NEW in 2026: foam packaging now accepted in the blue bin
notes: As of 2026, Circular Materials expanded acceptance to include foam packaging
Foam food containers are still NOT accepted — packaging only
commonMistakes: Only foam PACKAGING is accepted — not foam food containers
This is new for 2026

materials.name: Tubes (NEW 2026)
instructions: NEW in 2026: tubes now accepted in the blue bin
Squeeze out as much product as possible
notes: As of 2026, Circular Materials expanded acceptance to include tubes
commonMistakes: Squeeze out remaining product first
This is new for 2026

materials.name: Newspaper
notes: Newspapers go in blue bin in Ottawa, not the black bin
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper accepted
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: Window envelopes accepted — no need to remove plastic window
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in blue bin or beside it
notes: Large cardboard can be placed beside the blue bin on collection day
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove all packing materials

materials.name: Boxboard / paperboard
notes: Thin cardboard boxes accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic liners if possible

materials.name: Books
instructions: Damaged books: place in blue bin
notes: Donating is preferred
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the garbage

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag or clear bag
notes: Loose shredded paper is too small for sorting
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue bin

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place all food scraps in the green bin
Includes meat, bones, dairy, cooked food, raw food
Line bin with newspaper or certified compostable bag
notes: Ottawa green bin accepts all food waste
Green bin collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the garbage if you have green bin service
Don't use regular plastic bags

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Remove fruit stickers

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetables accepted
commonMistakes: Remove twist ties and elastic bands

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Includes raw and cooked meat, poultry, fish, bones
notes: Ottawa's industrial composting handles meat and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the garbage

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Recycle the container separately
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy in the garbage

materials.name: Bread and grains
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place coffee grounds, paper filters, and tea bags in green bin
notes: Paper filters accepted in Ottawa green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic-mesh tea bags in green bin

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush for faster breakdown

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green bin or use paper yard waste bags
Branches: bundle and tie, max 1m long and 7.5cm diameter
notes: Ottawa has seasonal leaf and yard waste collection in addition to green bin
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic
Don't include branches over size limit

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
notes: Ottawa green bin accepts food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin — it contaminates recycling

materials.name: Pizza box (greasy)
instructions: Greasy pizza boxes go in the green bin
Tear off clean portions for the blue bin
notes: Food-soiled cardboard accepted in Ottawa composting
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the blue bin

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: NOT accepted in Ottawa blue bin
Some grocery stores have plastic bag drop-off bins
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in Ottawa recycling
Note: flexible plastic packaging is now accepted as of 2026, but single-use bags should still go to store drop-off or garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic bags in the blue bin — they jam sorting machines

materials.name: Styrofoam food containers
instructions: Not accepted in Ottawa blue bin
notes: Expanded #6 polystyrene food containers not accepted
Note: foam PACKAGING is now accepted as of 2026, but food-service foam is still garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put foam food containers in the blue bin
Don't confuse with foam packaging which IS accepted in 2026

materials.name: Ceramics and drinking glasses
notes: Ceramics and drinking glasses contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin with glass bottles
Drinking glasses are different from container glass

materials.name: Window glass and mirrors
notes: Different composition from container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Light bulbs (non-CFL)
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs are hazardous waste — take to depot
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Large items: take to a scrap metal recycler or City of Ottawa Trail Road landfill
notes: Scrap metal is not accepted in Ottawa blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put scrap metal in the blue bin

materials.name: Metal hangers
instructions: Or return to dry cleaner for reuse
notes: Wire hangers tangle sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Hard plastics (non-container)
instructions: These are NOT accepted in Ottawa blue bin
notes: Only containers and packaging plastics are accepted in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic dishes, toys, or storage items in the blue bin

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green bin

materials.name: Pet waste
notes: Not accepted in Ottawa green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups and receipts
notes: Wax/plastic lining prevents cup recycling
Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in the blue bin
Don't put thermal receipts in the blue bin

materials.name: Candy and snack wrappers
notes: Multi-layer film cannot be separated for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to an Ottawa Trail Road Household Hazardous Waste depot
Or take to a participating retailer (Best Buy, Staples)
notes: Electronics banned from Ottawa landfill
Ontario Electronic Stewardship program
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside bin
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to an Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot
Or take to a participating retailer (Home Depot, Canadian Tire)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Batteries cause fires in trucks — never put in garbage or blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside bin
Tape terminals

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to Ottawa Trail Road Household Hazardous Waste depot
Or take to a paint retailer (many accept returns)
notes: Ontario paint stewardship program
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain
Don't put liquid paint in garbage

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications
notes: Ontario Medications Return Program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot
Or take to participating retailers (Home Depot, IKEA)
notes: Contains mercury — handle carefully
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage
Don't break them

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot
notes: Ontario Used Oil Materials Program
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot
Never put in any curbside bin
notes: Pressurized containers are explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in garbage

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Value Village, Goodwill, or Salvation Army
Textile recycling bins located throughout Ottawa
notes: Ottawa has multiple donation and textile recycling options
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside bin

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Take to Ottawa Trail Road landfill
Or schedule large item pickup through 311
notes: Appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside bin

materials.name: Alcohol containers (over 100ml)
instructions: Take to The Beer Store for deposit return
Wine and spirits bottles over 100ml go to The Beer Store
notes: Ontario deposit return system — refund available at The Beer Store
Containers under 100ml can go in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put deposit-eligible containers in the blue bin — get your refund!

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Take to an Ottawa pharmacy or Household Hazardous Waste depot
notes: Never place loose sharps in any bin
commonMistakes: Never put in any curbside bin

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data
Take to Best Buy, Staples, or a carrier store
notes: Phones contain valuable recoverable materials
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

recycle: Metal cans, jar lids, aluminum containers/foil (clean or food-soiled OK)
Empty paint cans (lids removed), empty aerosol cans
Rigid plastic containers #1-7 (bottles, jugs, jars, takeout, bakery, produce)
Plastic pails, planting trays, flower pots
Yogurt cups/tubs, clear plastic egg cartons
Milk/juice cartons, drink boxes, soup/broth cartons
Newspaper, magazines, office paper, cardboard, boxboard
NEW 2026: flexible plastic packaging, foam packaging, tubes
compost: ALL food waste — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Coffee grounds, paper filters, tea bags
Yard waste — grass, leaves, small branches

recycle: Ceramics, drinking glasses, window glass, mirrors
Hard plastics (non-container items like dishes, toys, storage totes)

tips: As of January 2026, Ottawa recycling is managed by Circular Materials (contractor: Miller Waste)
Items must be placed LOOSE in the blue bin — max 15kg weight
Food-soiled aluminum foil IS accepted — no need to scrub perfectly clean
Alcohol containers over 100ml go to The Beer Store for deposit refund
NEW in 2026: flexible plastic packaging, foam packaging, and tubes are now accepted in the blue bin
Only foam PACKAGING is accepted — foam food containers are still garbage
Ottawa uses blue bin (recycling), green bin (compost), and black bin (garbage)
Call 311 or visit ottawa.ca for disposal questions
Ottawa Household Hazardous Waste depot at Trail Road for batteries, paint, chemicals
Download the Ottawa Waste Explorer app for item-specific guidance

locations.name: Ottawa Trail Road Household Hazardous Waste Depot
The Beer Store (various locations)
locations.notes: Deposit refund available. Multiple locations across Ottawa.
